intro: Gilia ochroleuca, commonly known as the yellow gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, yellow or orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It has slender, branched stems and small, ovate leaves with hairy surfaces. The flowers are clustered in racemes and are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects.
